title: Fix harbor.sh parsing of docker desktop version
body:
Output of `docker compose version` looks like this under wsl:
```
$ docker compose version
Docker Compose version v2.31.0-desktop.2
```
This causes a warning when treating `patch_version` as numeric because it's `0-desktop`
author: bjj

comments.body: Thank you so much for the fix!

harbor$ harbor up librechat --remove-orphans
[+] Running 7/8

 âœ” Container harbor.librechat-db      Started                                       0.4s

 â ´ Container harbor.librechat         Starting                                      0.8s 
Error response from daemon: failed to create task for container: failed to create shim task: OCI runtime create failed: runc create failed: unable to start container process: error during container init: exec: "/app/start_librechat.sh": permission denied: unknown

harbor$ harbor shell librechat sh
[+] Creating 4/4

title: Harbor Doctor Error - fails to recognize newest docker compose
body:
$ harbor doctor
10:17:57 [INFO] Running Harbor Doctor...
10:17:58 [INFO] âœ” Docker is installed and running
10:17:58 [INFO] âœ” Docker Compose (v2) is installed
10:17:58 [ERROR] âœ˜ Docker Compose version is older than 2.23.1. Please update Docker Compose (v2).
10:17:58 [INFO] âœ” Harbor home: /home/admin/source/harbor
10:17:58 [INFO] âœ” Default profile exists and is readable
10:17:58 [INFO] âœ” Current profile (.env) exists and is readable
10:17:58 [INFO] âœ” CLI is linked
10:17:58 [INFO] âœ” NVIDIA GPU is available
10:17:58 [INFO] âœ” NVIDIA Container Toolkit is installed
10:17:58 [ERROR] Harbor Doctor checks failed. Please resolve the issues above.

$ docker-compose version
Docker Compose version v2.31.0-desktop.2
author: ColumbusAI

comments.body:
Hey, great to see you back!

Could you please also check the compose plugin v2, as that's what Harbor uses?

```bash
# Older compose, standalone binary
docker-compose version

# Newer compose, used by harbor, note no dash
docker compose version
```

With `docker compose` specifically, I see the following output:
```bash
# Older standalone binary
 everlier@pop-os:~$ â–¼ docker-compose version
Docker Compose version v2.20.3

# New v2 plugin
 everlier@pop-os:~$ â–¼ docker compose version
Docker Compose version v2.32.4

 everlier@pop-os:~$ â–¼ harbor doctor
00:41:44 [INFO] Running Harbor Doctor...
00:41:44 [INFO] âœ” Docker is installed and running
00:41:44 [INFO] âœ” Docker Compose (v2) is installed
# This line in doctor only checks v2 plugin, not standalone binary
00:41:44 [INFO] âœ” Docker Compose (v2) version is newer than 2.23.1
00:41:44 [INFO] âœ” Harbor home: /home/everlier/code/harbor
00:41:44 [INFO] âœ” Default profile exists and is readable
00:41:44 [INFO] âœ” Current profile (.env) exists and is readable
00:41:44 [INFO] âœ” CLI is linked
00:41:44 [INFO] âœ” NVIDIA GPU is available
00:41:44 [INFO] âœ” NVIDIA Container Toolkit is installed
00:41:44 [INFO] Harbor Doctor checks completed successfully.
```

you remembered me! Love it. Here's my docker compose version: 

$ docker-compose version
Docker Compose version v2.31.0-desktop.2

Yes, that's the older standalone binary, Harbor uses v2 plugin for docker CLI - the two can have different versions on same system. 

The difference is in the dash. 

I suspect that the v2 plugin could be older on your setup (or that Harbor has issues with "desktop" portion).

I traced the issue to this code snippet. When I commented out the last comparison, everything works as it should. The issue is that that the comparison was expecting an integer and received a string because of the "-desktop.2" but now we're all good! Closing this out.

```
 # log_debug "Docker Compose version: $major_version $minor_version $patch_version"

    if [ "$major_version" -lt "$desired_compose_major" ]; then
        # log_debug "Major version is less than $desired_compose_major"
        return 1
    fi

    if [ "$minor_version" -lt "$desired_compose_minor" ]; then
        # log_debug "Minor version is less than $desired_compose_minor"
        return 1
    fi

    #if [ "$patch_version" -lt "$desired_compose_patch" ]; then
        # log_debug "Patch version is less than $desired_compose_patch"
    #    return 1
    #fi
```

title: Auxiliary containers left running after harbor down
body:
When command `harbor down librechat` or `harbor down bionicgpt` is issued the "auxiliary" containers, such as `harbor.lc-db` `harbor.lc-vector` `harbor.lc-search` for Librechat are left running according to `docker ps`. Is this expected behavior? I could not find details in the documentation. I also noticed that these containers are not being removed upon `harbor down` and are still listed in `docker containers list --all`, unlike the "main" containers of the respective frontends.

-------------
I am running harbor version 1.35, on Bluefin DX (Fedora Silverblue 40).
author: FrantaNautilus

comments.body:
Thanks for trying things out!

No, it's not expected for those containers to remain running after `harbor down`, however that could happen if the down is cancelled prematurely.

I just tried following workflow locally and it doesn't seem to leave dangling containers:

```bash
 everlier@pop-os:~$ â–¼ h ps
NAME      IMAGE     COMMAND   SERVICE   CREATED   STATUS    PORTS

 everlier@pop-os:~$ â–¼ h u librechat
[+] Running 8/8
 âœ” Network harbor_harbor-network  Created                                                                                0.0s 
 âœ” Container harbor.webui         Healthy                                                                                6.6s 
 âœ” Container harbor.lc-db         Healthy                                                                                1.1s 
 âœ” Container harbor.lc-search     Healthy                                                                                1.1s 
 âœ” Container harbor.lc-vector     Healthy                                                                                1.1s 
 âœ” Container harbor.ollama        Healthy                                                                                1.1s 
 âœ” Container harbor.lc-rag        Healthy                                                                                1.0s 
 âœ” Container harbor.librechat     Healthy                                                                                1.0s 

 everlier@pop-os:~$ â–¼ h ps
NAME               IMAGE                                      COMMAND                  SERVICE     CREATED          STATUS                   PORTS
harbor.lc-db       mongo                                      "docker-entrypoint.sâ€¦"   lc-db       10 seconds ago   Up 9 seconds             27017/tcp
harbor.lc-search   getmeili/meilisearch:v1.7.3                "tini -- /bin/sh -c â€¦"   lc-search   10 seconds ago   Up 9 seconds             7700/tcp
harbor.lc-vector   ankane/pgvector:latest                     "docker-entrypoint.sâ€¦"   lc-vector   10 seconds ago   Up 9 seconds             5432/tcp
harbor.librechat   ghcr.io/danny-avila/librechat-dev:latest   "/app/start_librechaâ€¦"   librechat   10 seconds ago   Up 9 seconds             3080/tcp, 0.0.0.0:33891->33891/tcp, :::33891->33891/tcp
harbor.ollama      ollama/ollama:latest                       "/bin/ollama serve"      ollama      10 seconds ago   Up 9 seconds             0.0.0.0:33821->11434/tcp, :::33821->11434/tcp
harbor.webui       ghcr.io/open-webui/open-webui:main         "/app/start_webui.sh"    webui       10 seconds ago   Up 9 seconds (healthy)   0.0.0.0:33801->8080/tcp, :::33801->8080/tcp

 everlier@pop-os:~$ â–¼ h d
[+] Running 8/8
 âœ” Container harbor.webui         Removed                                                                                                                                         0.2s 
 âœ” Container harbor.ollama        Removed                                                                                                                                         0.2s 
 âœ” Container harbor.librechat     Removed                                                                                                                                        10.2s 
 âœ” Container harbor.lc-db         Removed                                                                                                                                         0.1s 
 âœ” Container harbor.lc-rag        Removed                                                                                                                                         0.0s 
 âœ” Container harbor.lc-search     Removed                                                                                                                                         0.1s 
 âœ” Container harbor.lc-vector     Removed                                                                                                                                         0.1s 
 âœ” Network harbor_harbor-network  Removed                                                                                                                                         0.2s 

 everlier@pop-os:~$ â–¼ h ps
NAME      IMAGE     COMMAND   SERVICE   CREATED   STATUS    PORTS

 everlier@pop-os:~$ â–¼ 
```

- No services are running
- `up librechat`, everything is running
- `down`
- No services are running

Could it be possible that you're `Ctrl+C`ing out of `harbor down`?  In that instance, not all dependencies might be resolved and containers indeed could be left handling. 

If this could be the case - I understand why you'd want to do that, as, `librechat` containers are left hanging on up/down for 10s, which is Docker's default timeout for unresponsive processes. Such waiting indicates incorrect setup for the service entrypoint, which is another thing that could be fixed here.

Thank  you for helping me with this issue. Trying this again and I found that the `harbor down`  works as expected, however its the command `harbor down <handle>`  which leaves containers running. The containers remain running even after 56 minutes.
```
$harbor down librechat
```
```
[+] Running 2/1
 âœ” Container harbor.librechat     Removed                                                                                                                                                                                                                        10.3s 
 ! Network harbor_harbor-network  Resource is still in use
```
```
$ harbor ps
```
```
NAME               IMAGE                                COMMAND                  SERVICE     CREATED          STATUS                    PORTS
harbor.lc-db       mongo                                "docker-entrypoint.sâ€¦"   lc-db       56 minutes ago   Up 56 minutes             27017/tcp
harbor.lc-search   getmeili/meilisearch:v1.7.3          "tini -- /bin/sh -c â€¦"   lc-search   56 minutes ago   Up 56 minutes             7700/tcp
harbor.lc-vector   ankane/pgvector:latest               "docker-entrypoint.sâ€¦"   lc-vector   56 minutes ago   Up 56 minutes             5432/tcp
harbor.ollama      ollama/ollama:latest                 "/bin/ollama serve"      ollama      56 minutes ago   Up 56 minutes             0.0.0.0:33821->11434/tcp, :::33821->11434/tcp
harbor.webui       ghcr.io/open-webui/open-webui:main   "/app/start_webui.sh"    webui       56 minutes ago   Up 56 minutes (healthy)   0.0.0.0:33801->8080/tcp, :::33801->8080/tcp
```
Only after running `harbor down` all containers were stopped and removed. Tested on CLI version: 0.2.0
Indeed, this is a bug in how the containers to stop are resolved, thank you for additional tests!
Is this not due to `docker compose up` rather than `docker compose up --remove-orphans` (or the compose down equivalent)?

The fix was released in one of the recent versions - down command now tries to match running sub-services as well. I'm closing this for now, but please feel free to follow-up or open a new one if needed.

title: Clarification on Frontend and Backend Compatibility with Multiple Models
body:
I have a few questions regarding frontend and backend compatibility:

1. Frontend-Backend Compatibility: Does any frontend work with any backend? I noticed that most backends are designed to work with GGUF models, but this project seems to support various backends, including vLLM, Mistral.rs, etc. If I select one of these backends, will it be compatible with frontends like Open WebUI and other similar platforms?
2. Closed-Source Frontend Support: Currently, I have a closed-source frontend that is only compatible with GGUF models. If I choose to use this project, is it possible to expose a backend that my closed-source frontend can consume, allowing it to support multiple types of backends?

Iâ€™d appreciate any guidance or clarification on these points!
author: bhupesh-sf

comments.body:
Thanks for trying out Harbor!

1. It's only mentioned in the docs implicitly, but the support is not complete (nor it could be, to be fair)

The policy is to support everything for the main default UI and default Backend. I.e. - integrate all UIs with the default backend and all UIs with the default backend. Anything else is considered extra and provided on the best effort basis (contributions are very welcomed!)

This is not to discourage you in any way - plenty of services combinations work out of the box, the best way to check is to lookup the `x` files to see if there's an intersection.

2. All the Harbor services that expose the APIs can be used with external clients. See docs on the `harbor url` / `harbor qr` commands
Thanks for the answer, it does clarifies ðŸ‘ðŸ»
Awesome, feel free to reopen if needed

title: Permission issue with LibreChat Deployment
body:
Hello,

I'm running into a permission issue when deploying LibreChat under Harbor. I get the following error when starting the container:
```
> LibreChat@v0.7.5-rc2 backend
> cross-env NODE_ENV=production node api/server/index.js

2024-09-17 11:37:21 info: [Optional] Redis not initialized. Note: Redis support is experimental.
2024-09-17 11:37:23 error: There was an uncaught error: EACCES: permission denied, open '/app/api/logs/meiliSync-2024-09-17.log'
```

Then the container stops and exits.

I tried reverting to an older image version than the latest one but I still get the same error.
I also tried setting the variables PUID and PGID to 1000.
None of this worked.

Deploying with the docker-compose file from the original LibreChat repository does not have this issue.
author: maeyounes

comments.body: I solved this problem by adding the line `user: ":"` to the docker compose file as the original repository had `user: "${UID}:${GID}"`. It does not work with value 1000 for `UID` and `GID` for some reason.

Sorry, you were so quick I didn't manage to provide the feedback in time!

FS permissions are a classic issue when mounting host volumes with docker. So, there's a built-in (underdocumented, though) util to fix:

```bash
harbor fixfs
```

It'll prompt you for the user password and will run as `root`, updating the permissions on folders of most of the services.

I didn't document it better cause it's kind of a workaround and I'm hoping to find a better answer in time. You'd also need to re-run it every once in a while when such permission issues re-occur.

title: Bug: Harbor ollama <parameter>
body:
OCI runtime exec failed: exec failed: unable to start container process: exec: "ollama list": executable file not found in $PATH: unknown

I removed my host ollama (rm /usr/local/bin/ollama, userdel ollama...). Maybe that caused this issue, idk.

Edit: entering on container and running "ollama list" works, just "harbor ollama list" or "harbor exec ollama "ollama list" doesn't works.
author: alsoasnerd

comments.body:
Thank you for reporting! It's a regression after resolving some of the linter messages in the main CLI file - went a tad wrong (sorry for the inconvenience)

Please run `harbor update` and it should be fixed
Closing as config override was fixed
